thread.title: Surf, sand, start-up: Tech boom in Byron Bay
thread.title_full: Surf, sand, start-up: Tech boom in Byron Bay | Business Spectator

author: Krishan Sharma
title: Surf, sand, start-up: Tech boom in Byron Bay
text:
Moving a business from a big city such as Sydney to a regional town is likely to present a host of challenges for most companies, but the change in scenery has helped turn start-up Jack Media into one of the Asia-Pacific’s fastest-growing technology companies.
Founder James Kitchener says the surf and sand of Byron Bay in northern NSW has provided the ideal work-life balance and cheaper rent has reduced overheads.
“We had the ability to live anywhere but Byron had a lot of the values we wanted to ingrain into the business,” Kitchener says.
Jack Media took shape while Kitchener was snowboarding in Canadian ski town Whistler.
“I had just sold my first digital business and co-founder Andrew Crawley was looking to start his first business after working in multiple digital agencies,” he says.
The business kickstarted off the back of the rapid growth of daily deal outfits in 2011, picking up clients like Groupon, Living Social and Ozsale.
After a year, Kitchener and Crawley decided to set up offices in Byron Bay.
According to Kitchener, there were a few hurdles but nothing that couldn’t be overcome.
“I would love faster internet, but this isn’t a huge issue because the speeds we have are more than adequate. The other hurdle is client face-to-face meetings but, with two airports nearby, it’s only a short cheap flight anywhere on the east coast and we can be home for dinner in Byron after a day of meetings in Sydney.”
Since the move, the online marketing company has turned over $6 million in just four years. Kitchener says running the business from one of Australia’s most iconic destinations has been a “competitive advantage’’ especially when it comes to retaining staff.
In fact, all of Jack Media’s eight internal staff have been lured from Sydney.
Byron Bay quietly boasts a growing tech scene of its own and is home to several other successful tech start-ups such as ­TripADeal, 30acres and Aeeris in addition to numerous indie app developers.
The other reason for Jack Media’s success is the in-house built Signup Partners platform, which enables clients to build lead generation marketing campaigns in “a matter of minutes’’ via a drag and drop interface.
Kitchener says it normally requires a team of coders and designers to develop but, through the use of their platform, clients can build responsive landing pages for various campaigns and start collecting relevant lead generation data in a few clicks.
“Signup Partners has been so successful because there is no comparable product on the market and there is a huge demand from in-house marketers for help with the digital customer acquisition,” Kitchener says. “The platform allows us to win and retain premium clients and then quickly scale and automate marketing campaigns and spend based on ­results.
“We save our clients thousands in design and development time to become more agile and responsive.”
He says coupling the platform with a results-based model, where clients pay only for leads generated by their campaigns, has played a pivotal role in the company’s growth.
“It allows new clients to trial our services with very little risk,” Kitchener says.
“We also have access to an incredible amount of data so we can easily demonstrate the impact of our services on the client’s bottom line.”
